headline: The Lead with Jake Tapper
subHeadline: Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis Testifies. Aired 4- 5p ET

utterances.speaker: FANI WILLIS, FULTON COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: I'll give $51. I don't operate like that with my girlfriends. I don't operate like that with anyone. He caught the bill, I caught the bill, whomever.

utterances.speaker: ASHLEIGH MERCHANT, ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Did you ever pay him through cash app?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You only ever paid him through cash?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What -- yes. We'll talk about --- I'm very confused now, like --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You've never given Mr. Wade money through cash app?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: The only money you've ever given him outside of a contract is cash?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I didn't give him money in a contract, so that was cute. But I didn't give him money out -- in a contract.What happened at -- no, we go answer it since you said it. He worked -- he worked more hours than he was paid and the county paid him for the work that he did. So don't be cute with me and then think that you're not going to get an answer.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And I will ask you about the contract in a minute. I asked you about cash.Did you ever pay him anything -- and I'm trying to qualify my questions. I'm not talking about the contract with Fulton County that was paid. I'm not talking about that. Talking about outside of that, did you ever pay him anything other than cash?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I've only give them cash a few times and in the course of what we're talking about. If we would go to dinner --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Let her finish. WILLIS

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Probably the most money I've ever handed him is $2,500. The least amount of money I've handed him probably $2,500 and $1,000.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You never wrote them a check.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Ma'am, I don't have checks

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So you have no proof of any reimbursement for any of these things because it was all cash, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: The testimony of one witness is enough to prove a fact.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So my question was --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Are you telling me that I'm lying to you? Is that what you're intimating right here?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm asking if you have any proof that you paid any of these monies.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I mean, the prove is what I just told you.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You have no written proof. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So I have some probably some transactions like in Belize, I probably spent $500 on my card in Belize. I spent 800 -- I can't remember 900 bucks on each of our tickets to go to Belize. I did the $700, I probably got some minor expenses in Aruba that would be on a card.But for the most part, for those trips, other than -- so the two cruises, I gave him money for those before we ever left because they were pre-booked. Let me answer --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So, the question was if you had any written proof? And so --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So, I've answered you that I've had written --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: We can move the next question if you've answered. If you had any written proof and that was my question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I want to make sure that were clear that for the two cruises --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant, she answered your question, so we can ask the next question.  Ms. Willis, in the cross, you'll have plenty of opportunities to let you clarify her answers when it's your turn.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Judge.Knowing your role is district attorney, know that public funds are scrutinized and money is scrutinized and things like that, you understand? (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You understand you're under a microscope. You have reporting requirements. All of those types of things. You have no record other than your testimony of the money that you've given Mr. Wade.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: You've already asked that question. Let's keep going.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: When you took office, you had a tax lien of $4,600. Did you pay that with cash when you made that tax lien hole?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I probably paid through however you pay.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay. So but you were saying that you had amounts of cash. You still had that lien in 2022 when you were thinking, wait and going on these trips. So the cash that you gave him that could have been used to pay this tax lien off.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: You want to tell me how to pay my bills?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I object. This is not relevant as it relates to (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant, if you are you trying to establish that she was insolvent in some way?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I definitely was trying to establish that she did not have these mass amounts of cash that she's talking about? Yes.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: All right. Ask -- re-ask the question.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You had to tax lien in 2020 to $4,600.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: If you say I did.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you did not use this cash that you had to reimburse Mr. Wade to pay that off, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I went shopping, too, when I didn't pay it all.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And you talked about that you gave a lot of interviews to an author and finding the (INAUDIBLE) right? WILLIS(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- questions relevant as to --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: I think it's already come up that finances are discussed in the book. I'll overrule that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Wilson, continue your answer.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What came up with Mr. Wade as hearsay statements that he was asked about in relation to what Ms. Willis may or may not have said in relation to an op-ed. So, that's not relevant to testimony, according at this time.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So you gave interviews to the authors of this book, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Once or twice.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Three times, and just to be comprehensive. I don't know if it was three times. Two or three times, I think.

utterances.speaker: MRECHANT
utterances.sentences: You were quoted in the book and I will give you a chance to say if this is a misquote, you're quoted, I -- when they asked you about if you wanted to run for office for D.A., you were quoted, I really don't want to be financially f'ed up again, do you remember saying that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So what that refers to --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So my question first is if you remember saying that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I remember saying something similar to that, but I would like to be able to explain what that's in reference to.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: That's fine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's not in reference to anything else. It was a huge sacrifice to be district attorney of Fulton County, huge. I was doing just fine. I had a municipal court judgeship that was paying me 100- something-thousand dollars a year, and like you've got to show up twice a week. Easiest thing, I've ever done in life.I also had private clients that were paying me to represent them. So I was able to have a law practice and that. Raising two daughters by myself, there were times in life where things were hard. And so I was telling people, I don't really run for D.A. I don't want to run for D.A. I mean, a good position right now. I got this easy job that I enjoy being the chief judge of the city of South Fulton, making money at the law firm. And I'm not sure that I want to make the sacrifice. And why does it always have to be me? Eventually, I prayed. I think that I was the appropriate person. I think that I did that. So when you're referring to that, what I'm saying is why should I make a sacrifice again? And what I was not talking about is being district attorney. Once you get elected district attorney, you're in a fine financial position. I make over $200,000 a year. What I was talking about is I ran for judge. When I ran for judge, I took $50,000 of my personal money out of my retirement and that money ended up being lost. And I know when you bet on yourself, you're going to have to bet money on yourself. And so, what I was talking about was not wanting to go to the personal financial expense of running for office. By no means that I think that I was going to be financially in a bad position once I won. Let's talk about what I was up against because it's important to understand that comment. I had a district attorney who had been here for 24 years. You put -- no, no, no, this is very relevant as to what my mindset was about this. So I'm trying to answer your question. So what I was saying is --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: So it's a finance.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Right. But it is about my finances if I didn't -- nobody put me in this seat, so I had already run for office once. I had spit $50,000 of my own money running and it was then moot, nothing.And so when I'm talking to those offers, I'm talking about the contemplation of the sacrifice of the run, not the sacrifice of once you become D.A. The odds were against me. I was likely going to lose the election based on who I was running against. So that needs to be in the appropriate context.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Isn't it true that the authors also wrote and you can dispute this if you'd like, that you were broke after that race?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: The 2018 race.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, that was a hard race. I wasn't broke like I didn't have any broke is relative to depending where you are, but that hurt to lose that $50,000. So I'm sure my mental mindset was like I just gave 50,000 hours away.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Right. So they characterized it from their conversations with you that you were broke, you had poured your own money into the campaign and you weren't able to pay your own bills because of your I'm sorry -- your clients couldn't pay their bills to you and you had a paltry array of family and asset forfeiture cases. It says you were trying to make it month to month.Is that an accurate depiction of your financial situation that point?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I would want to read that, but I don't -- I don't remember clients not being able to pay their bills. So --

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: That part, Judge?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: You may.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I have not read this book.So -- so like this fact here, her ex-husband Fred (INAUDIBLE) to a financial -- I have no information about that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I didn't ask you about that. I just asked about if you were -- what they represent from their interviews and then you had clients that want able to pay their bills.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Can you show me where that is? Because this is where you put the tabs. So that's what I read.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Broke, but couldn't pay their bills.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, that that I'm sure I characterize myself. I was broke as leaving that $50,000. I don't know that I had-- her nascent law practice had paltry, I didn't have --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So, my question was just if this was a fair and accurate representation where it says you are trying to make it month to month, that that --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think that that is actually a fair and accurate representation, but I am certain that after the 2018 election I'm still not really happy about having given up that 50,000.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Do you know when you paid your tax lien?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You don't. You know if you've paid it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I know I've paid some taxes. I don't know. I don't want to speculate.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did you tell anyone at Fulton County Board of County Commissioners about your relationship with Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did you disclose your relationship to anybody at Fulton County?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No. I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: And as the chief law enforcement officer, Fulton County, I assume that you're familiar with the county code and warden ordinances.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: I've said we're not going to cover that in this hearing, Ms. Merchant.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, Judge.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: I said we weren't going to cover the county regulations.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay. I won't.Let me ask you this then. So are you aware that you're required to disclose any relationship with someone that you contract within Fulton County?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I object, the court's prior ruling this morning made.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Would this be different because its potential for impeachment?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What did you ask me?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Merchant, you need to re-ask the question.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. Are you aware that Fulton County requires you to disclose any relationship with someone that you're doing business with?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm not aware and I know often that time -- things are confused with state constitutional officers in county, but I'm not aware.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay. So it's not your -- so it's your understanding that you don't have a duty to disclose the relationship?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: She's answered that question. Let's keep going. MERCHANT

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What do you talk -- I don't understand.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Did you keep track? Did you keep a ledger? Did you keep track of it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So I'm only giving him cash as I mentioned, three or four times. There's no ledger. This is friends handing money off to each other.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So the answer is no.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: I think you've already asked whether there was any written proof whatsoever and she's answered that.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: So we've covered this. Let's move on.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Who are you referring to when you suggested that Mr. Roman's motion to disqualify was racially motivated?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: We've already said we're not talking about forensic misconduct that's been alleged.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And just so the record is clear, I don't believe I said that he has motion was racially motivated, so I don't want that to stay there. Ive never said his motion was racially motivated. So that -- that should not be true.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: It would be best if we don't need to go down that road. Were going to save that for argument.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: You want to said that you would not engage with a personal relationship with anyone that worked for Fulton County, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: An employee?

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Anyone that worked for Fulton County.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I think I said an employee.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: OK. So that's the qualification you gave, an employee.  You would not --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I think that's the statement that I made. So if you want to quote, quote me accurately.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: So it's your position because Mr. Wade was not an employee or is your position he wasn't an employee, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Mr. Wade is not an employee and he will tell you that over and over again.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Just one moment, Judge.I'm sorry, this statement so I make sure I accurately quote you. What you said was you won't work -- you won't sleep with people who work under you. Do you not consider Mr. Wade working under you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I consider Mr. Wade to be an agent.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: An agent?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And a point  is what I really think of him as.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Your point, whatever merit it has, Ms. Merchant, is on the record.

utterances.speaker: MERCHANT
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Judge.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Next question.Al right. We need any moments, in a minute. Mr. Sadow?

utterances.speaker: STEVE SADOW, ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: All right

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm going to try to ask you questions that you can actually answer without having to explain, okay?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. My comprehension skills are pretty good, so we should do all right.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: We shall soon see.If I heard you correctly, you moved into what I will refer to as the Yeartie condo in either March or April of 2021. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK. And is that Yeartie condo, would you say that it is in Hapeville?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: It is in Hapeville. Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And you moved in there for safety reasons?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: My father -- yes. I moved in the amount we were concerned. My father was terribly concerned about me continuing to live at the house. And so they will clear people came to my house at 05a wake-up call. There were security threats due to gang cases, and there were concerns due to the -- that was at the very beginning of this looking into that. And so, for all of those reasons and what was happening, my father wanted me out the house and begrudgingly, I left.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. So the answer the question was yes, for safety reasons, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Those were all of the things that cause the safety concerns. I'm sorry --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm questioning whether they are or not safety concerns. I just ask that you moved into this condo, Yeartie condo --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: -- for safety reasons, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: At the time that you moved into the condo, be it from February to April of 2021, was your fathers still living in your house?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Right, because my father --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That's all I asked you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: But I get to claim the answer, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I don't know if there's an explanation. If I ask you, was your father still living at your house? The answer is either he was or he wasn't.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes. But you are going to get to argue at the end of this as we both know.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to argue anything. I'm going to ask --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So, I would like to be able to explain why.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Because my father is an older gentleman. He was worried about COVID, and he stayed.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Ms. Willis, I'm going to have to say that's second time, whenever we had to put a pause, you stop testifying, okay? You all have a chance to explain yourself.The question was whether your father was not staying there at the time and you're clarifying that -- in your answer as well. You can have a brief clarification, but it shouldn't be something that reaches well beyond the question. All right. Mr. Sadow, you can re-ask the question. We'll see where it takes us.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. Thank you, Your Honor.Was your father still living in your house at the time you moved to what I would refer to as Yeartie condo?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir, he was due to his concerns related to COVID.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK. The safety concern was that there was potential danger at your house. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes. My address had been exposed. So yes, there was concerns about potential danger at my house.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK. So anyone staying at your house in the time period after you went to the Yeartie condo was still in danger, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. What -- no, no.  He did --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: I think you have to -- it's your attorney, Ms. Willis. Sorry, Mr. Pottinger. Objection is speculation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: To the question of --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: It is speculation.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: -- whether someone was still in danger at her condo?(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I can --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Just let her answer the question.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Sadow wants to rephrase.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I was able to understand it.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I've got the objection and then I have --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I withdraw the objection --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And I remember the question, so I can answer it.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Or you can now that the objection has been withdrawn, can you try to answer that question?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: There's still a safety concern for people staying at the house. WILLIS

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.During that period that you left to go to the Yeartie condo, did any of your children stay at your house?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So I don't -- I don't think that they were there at that point. Certainly my baby wasn't there.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm talking about this entire period. We're talking about -- if I remember correctly, and you'll correct me. I'm sure. You said that you stay there at what I would call the Yeartie condo until January of 2022, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. So I'm asking you in that period, which would be February to April of 2021 until January of '22, did any of your children stay at your house?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK. So if I continue to go into more detail on this, you're not going to be able to give me an answer of whether or not in fact any of your children we're still at the house or stayed at your house during that time period, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What I can give you clarity of so that we are clear is from the time I moved out in February-ish of 2021, after I left there, there was a time period that my oldest daughter came back. But if you're asking me, was it in that window or after, I just don't have a recollection of that because, you know, your kids come and they go. And so I don't remember the specific time period and I apologize for that.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Did your children ever stay with you at the Yeartie condo? WILLIS

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Like for a girls night or something, but live with? No.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Did anyone else stay with you at the Yeartie condo, including Ms. Yeartie?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Never. Ms. Yeartie never lived in condo. She met her husband and they move they weren't quite married, but they moved. Nobody ever live with me in the condo. That was --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: My word. My word was stayed, not lived. Stayed with you at the condo?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I guess I don't understand the distinction, but no one ever -- I think my babies -- my oldest child I think she spent one night with me, maybe my oldest and my youngest. But I think that whole time I was in that place other than that one night, I don't think anyone ever -- does very lonely period in my time -- life. I don't think anyone ever spent the night other than maybe one night. I remember a picture of my babies sitting on the couch in that place. And I'm thinking she spent that night. But just a very lonely time in life.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK. We'll stay with the lonely theme just for a minute.Did Nathan Wade visit you at the Yeartie condo from the time you moved in until he was hired on November the 1st of 2021?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So I moved out of that condo, but during that time period, yeah, I'm sure he came to visit. He came to visit. I can remember us going -- I think that restaurants Lickety-Split. I can remember him picking me up one Lickety-Split, eaten, ordered some food and coming and sitting at my table and eating. So I remember times that he visited me at that condo, yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Could you give us an approximation of how many times Mr. Wade visited you at the condo between the time you moved in and prior to November 1 of 2020.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't think often, but I don't re -- I don't want to speculate.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Can we say more than five? More than ten?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to tell you the problem I'm having here. Let's say more than ten, but I'm not sure that that's even accurate. He certainly has come and pick me up, grab some food to eat. I don't remember him being in that condo a lot.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That your --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't -- I'm sorry. Do you want a number? And what I don't want to do --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Giving me your current and best recollection is all I'm asking for.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's all I can give you, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: How many times did any of the prosecution team -- how many times did Anna Cross come to that condo between the time you moved in in November 1st of 2021?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't think Anna has ever been to that condo.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: What about any other prosecutor that's involved in the prosecution of this case?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't think any of them have.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Just Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's correct, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: But it was a lonely time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God that, yeah. That 2021, I have a lot of guilt about this time period in my life. Let me tell you why, but yes, it was a lonely time.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I was very appreciative to the citizens for giving me this responsibility and this duty. But what I'm very, very quickly learned is that this is a very isolating job. And 2021 was a lonely time. I turned 50 in 2021, probably one of the worst birthdays I've ever had. I spent it alone. So I have a clear recollection of 2021 being lonely.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Did Mr. Wade, ever visit you at the condo? The time period I'm talking about prior to November of 2021 when Ms. Yeartie was at the condo?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So, Ms. Yeartie and me, we didn't share the condo at the same time.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So the answer would be no.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Well, we never stayed them together, so it's an impossibility.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: It's an impossibility?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Well, maybe that was clear, but I'm going to have to try again.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Was Ms. Yeartie still living in the condo when you moved in?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Not a day.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. So what I'm talking --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: -- misrepresentation in this. We never lived together. I never lived with Ms. Yeartie.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: My question, though, I'm trying to understand that. After you moved in to the condo, Ms. Yeartie had been -- she was out of the condo, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: She got a house.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That's all I'm asking. She's not in the condo.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: She is -- we never stay, Ms. Yeartie and I never stay a day together in the condo. All of her stuff was out of the condo and all my stuff -- some of my stuff, not all of it obviously was moved into the conduct. So we never stayed there together. No, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right.So when I asked you about Mr. Wade visiting the condo --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: -- when you were staying there --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: -- wasn't staying there, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That will be correct, yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: She wouldn't be at the condo, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No, she would not have been.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: It would be you and Mr. Wade alone at the condo, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That is -- there weren't any other witnesses to Mr. Wade and you at the condo, correct

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes. SADOW

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I object. She said it was just her and Mr. Wade.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: You made your point, Mr. Sadow. Let's move on to the next one.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, Your Honor.Who in the prosecution team prior to I guess, the motion being filed by defendant Roman, who in the prosecution team, knew of your personal relationship and now I'm talking romantic with Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So, sir, I am extremely private.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I asked you who knew. It's not -- if the answer is no one knew. That's fine.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I ask you, who knew him?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Answer and explain, Ms. Willis.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I am very private. When I supervise Mr. Body (ph) and Mr. McAfee (ph), they didn't know who I was dating, but I can assure you I was dating somebody. So that I kept something private. That's my private life is not any mystery to anyone.It's like a woman doesn't have the right to keep our private life private. And I'm speaking on this because there have been all these intimations.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: So on answering the question, Ms. Willis.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, what was the question in, Your Honor?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Is there anyone else who knew about it and then you can explain.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I don't think so. I certainly didn't go out telling my business to the world.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So the best of your recollection, you didn't inform anyone on the prosecution team that the individual that you had chosen to lead the prosecution team had a personal relationship with you, but that correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's inaccurate. Your question is inaccurate.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: What --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: You stated that the person I chose, we had a personal relationship, so we had a friendship. We have -- we have all these distinguishing factors.Remember, when I chose him in November of '21. First of all, lets get district Mr. Wade was not actually my first choice. That's no insult to him.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Your Honor, I don't --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No, because of the way you phrased the question you said, when I chose him, I didn't inform people of a personal relationship. We have defined personal as romantic. It is an inaccurate way to state the question and --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Then I will certainly restate so it is very accurate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Okay. And please do not yell at me.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You hired Mr. Wade for the first time on November 1st of 2021, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: November of 2021? Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Your testimony is, whether one accepts it or not, your testimony is, but at the time you hired Mr. Wade, there had never been a romantic relationship with Mr. Wade before you hire him, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes. My testimony is that we were very good friends, but not we're talking about sex. So let's just don't --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm not talking about -- I'm saying romantic relationship doesn't necessarily have to be just sex. It can be updating. It can be holding hands. It can be any of those things that one might call romantic. I'm asking you whether or not prior to November 1st of 2021, there was a romantic relationship with Mr. Wade? That's very simple. It's either a yes or no?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't consider my relationship with him to be romantic before that. I'm not a hold -- hand-holder. So, no.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That's fine.Now, its moved beyond November 1st of 2020 --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: 2021, excuse me? I understand your testimony. There was no romantic relationship with Mr. Wade until early in 2022, whether it'd be January or February or March, early in 2022, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I will say sometime between February and April, yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: All right. Now, I'm asking you about that time period when it became romantic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. You didn't see the need if I understand to tell any of the people onthe prosecution team when you had established a romantic relationship with Mr. Wade, that the lead prosecutor that is the people -- man that was basically giving orders to others was dating or having a romantic relationship with you, correct?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I object to relevance at this point, Your honor.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: So, no relevance?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Just to prove or attempting to show that there is an issue on the credibility about the relationship, the failure to have informed anyone, anyone on her team that she was having a romantic relationship with the lead prosecutor? I suggest gives rise to that inference, that's the rub of the inference.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: The inference that?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: The inference that -- that they were concealing this because it was not as it's been characterized, the court and then in fact, it started earlier than what they say.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: All right. Overrule, Mr. Sadow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I just want to make sure that we're clear, from at least 2020. Me and Mr. Wade were friends, at least that time period.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay, I'm not talking about --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So, no, no, I want to be clear because my credibility is being evaluated here, right? We were friends. We hung out prior to November of 2021. In November of 2021, I hired him. I do not consider our relationship to have become romantic until early of 2022 because I don't know what date and time, I'm saying sometime between February and April of 2022 and very early April of 2022, because I know that trip that I discussed with you was the first week of 2022, that the relationship had become romantic.I hope that answered your question, but I can't have it where, you know, we're saying something differently.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: So, you established the timeline, as you put it, the question originally was at the time -- at that time, did you tell any other prosecutors or the prosecution team.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I never told people at work whom I'm dating.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: All right.Mr. Sadow?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK. Did you take any trips to D.C. with Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Never.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Did you ever -- did you take -- okay. So do you have no -- what I would call personal trips or business trips to D.C. with Mr. Wade.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I never went to D.C. with Mr. Wade personal, business, otherwise, never.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I've never been in the District of Columbia with Mr. Wade or Maryland, Virginia, the DMV as they call it.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So as I understand it, to be clear, any trips that you would have taken to see D.C. would not --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: That was a pretty clear answer.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Huh?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: That was a pretty clear answer. She just said no.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Twice.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: So you have a variation or something new to bring up.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'll ask it and well see. Did you take trips to dc that were non-business during the time period that this case of this matter was under investigation?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to relevance as relates to the matter that we're here before, Your Honor.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Well, again, the question he asked take personal or business trips. She said --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: But I -- but that was with Mr. Wade. That was with Mr. Wade. This I asked her alone whether she took.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What's the relevance?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: What would be the relevance of that?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Trying to understand whether or not we have an ability to show a personal trip in which Mr. Wade is there at the same time. I understand her answer. Oka? I understand her answer, but we have documents. We have records that --(INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Well, this could be something that's maybe not part of the record yet, but if he as -- I think there have been other things discuss in this case and they have evidence that Mr. Wade may have been in D.C. at the same time. If you want to ask about that exact specific date, Mr. Sadow, you can do that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I would reference to the court that that was not asked of Mr. Wade anything about any trips to D.C.? JUDGEcredibility. So, Mr. Sadow, ask the question.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So I understand your testimony is you'd never took a trip to D.C. with Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Personal or business?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Were you ever in dc at the same time as Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I was not --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: -- on personal or business?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: My next question is based on her opening the door, and therefore, I'll just ask it in, Your Honor, can decide whether or not it's appropriate when you went to D.C., did you go to the White House?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I did not go to the White House.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Well, apparently I'm going to get the answer anyhow.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: There you have it. Next question.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. You indicated your best recollection was that you relationship with Mr. Wade, a romantic relationship, ended -- you will have to get -- August of 2023. That sound right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That's the hard conversation. That's not the --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: We've covered this. Next question.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And you characterize it as a tough conversation? Correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. I'm not going to get into the conversation per se.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: You should.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Well, if he doesn't want to, we won't go there.So, Mr. Sadow, next question.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: It's kind of hard to say no when you've got that opportunity. But I'm going to say is, was it pre-indictment in this case?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: We know the timeline that the indictment was delivered.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: And so that we're clear, the physical relationship ended pre- indictment.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And is that when you were talking about the tough conversation?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: But the phy -- I'm not sure that the tough conversation didn't happen until after, but the physical relationships, so I'm sure if you ask Mr. Wade because he's a male, he would say we ended June or July because physical contact ended then.Just in my mind, being a woman, it's over when you have that like hard conversation. That's -- I just think women and men think differently.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: And I think the answer Mr. Sadow, out of your question was she's not sure whether it was before or after the indictment.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm not -- I'm not sure that that was her answer, but let's see if I can get specific.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That is what I said. That's what I said.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: I let you. Next question, Mr. Sadow, if you need to clarify.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I want to say one more. The romantic relationship ended before the indictment was returned? Yes or no?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: To a man, yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: To a man, yes. To you, no?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: She's explained this, Mr. Sadow. She's explained.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And the -- did the forthcoming indictment have anything to do with that? Or was it just a coincidence.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Mister -- let's go on and have the conversation.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I've just asked you whether or not it was a coincidence. WILLISWe would have brutal arguments about the fact that I am your equal. I don't need anything from a man. A man is not a plan. A man is a companion. And so there was tension always in our relationship, which is why I was give him his money back. I don't need anybody to foot my bills. The only man who's ever put my bills completely is my daddy.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Is there anything else you'd like to add to that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm sure we'll talk about it further.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: No, we're not going to talk about it further.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: All right. No back-and-forth, Mr. Sadow, next question.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: My next question is something that I would -- that has to do with the -- what I've characterized as the church speech. Let me just tell you what the question is, because I know that's not --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Reserve for the record.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Huh?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: You can preserve the question for the record, but then well move on.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That's correct. Thank you.When you gave what I've referred to as the Martin Luther King weekend church speech. You know what I'm referring to?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: A great honor of mine, that's a historic African American church. Yes, I do.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Did you have handwritten notes with you that you were reading from during the speech?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: And on second thought, Mr. Sadow, because you might have a number of questions about this. Why don't we just bullet point what you would want to cover on this reserved for the record, then well move on to the next topic.Since I had laid out before that the forensic misconduct doesn't -- (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I do not get an answer for that?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. Did you read your speech?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Look, no. Mr. Sadow, for everything related to any forensic --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You just wanted to stay out of it now?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: We're just not -- we can do it in a bullet form. If you just want to cover what you would've asked -- but it's not in a question- and-answer format.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So I should do that at this point or do it?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: When you're ready --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: We can do it right now, so it's fresh and --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I will love to answer those questions.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Well, Ms. Willis, you can certainly do that in some other format. But for today, that's what decided were not going to cover.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Who is she talking about that was playing the race card? And why she didn't tell the people at the church that she was -- that she had had a personal/romantic relationship with the -- all due respect the way it was characterized -- the Black man that she was referring to, and was the Black man she refer referring to, was that Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So that's that area of inquiry.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Noted for the record, Mr. Sadow. Next topic?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: OK. I realized that you've testified that you have no records with regard to cash payments.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Correct? WILLIS

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Would your bank records reflect that you withdrew cash from your bank accounts during the time period of 2020, 2021, 2021, 2022, or 2023?I'm not asking you -- I'm just asking whether they would reflect that you would cash from any of your bank accounts?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: The exact amounts?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Well, just in fact, you did.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Of course, I withdrew money throughout the time period throughout my life. I withdraw money from the bank. Yes. Of course.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Talking about cash from -- that is that you go to a bank or you go to an ATM and you take cash out.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Either that way or you go to Publix and you overpay or you go to another store and you overpay. So yes, both through that? Yes. Of course, they will reflect that at times.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. And those records, if we have them, would show that, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: That throughout the course of our life, I drawn out money.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I was very specific, I said 2020 --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes. During the course of that time period, I would have taken money out. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So do you have a problem with re --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I absolutely. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You don't want the bank records to be made available for the court and the court alone.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm going to object to the relevance and this is already been addressed earlier as it relates to other records. This is an improper line of question -- questioning, doing it to the purpose of harassing. For the purpose of --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: I'm just going to sustain it on relevance.Mr. Sadow, that's something you want to follow up privately. You can do that.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Last area briefly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You had contact with Mr. Wade in the year 2020, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Ooh. I had some contact with Mr. Wade.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Would you explain when you say some contact? Please tell us the -- I'm talking about 2020.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I had some contact with Mr. Wade in 2020. One of the reasons, your allegations are so preposterous or Ms. Merchants that you have going is --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Ma'am, I didn't ask you about the allegations. I asked you about your contact. It's all I ask you. Okay?I appreciate that. You want to say something, but I'm interested in -- did you have contacts with Mr. Wade in 2020 and your answer so far has been yes, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Very limited contact because Mr. Wade had a form of cancer. It makes your allegations somewhat ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I do appreciate the characterization --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to emasculate a Black man, but I'm just telling you --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to emasculate a Black man. Did you understand that? I don't think we should discuss further.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: All right. Let's get back on track.Mr. Sadow, next question?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Trying to, Your Honor. Would you tell us on the occasions in 2020 that you add contact with Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, I thought I had answered that, yes. Yes. So there were times in 2020 I had contact, but 2020 was a year I was running for office. It was a year that he was going through some serious medical issues, and I did not have much contact. But I certainly had contact with him in 2020 --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Did you go out to eat with him?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Maybe probably.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Did you -- did you visit him in any location? His office or did he visit you in your office in 2020?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I am sure he -- I'm sure -- that's a very good question. I'm sure he came to 750 in 2020.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What's my office.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Okay. WILLISoffice once or twice, but maybe once.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And the purpose for going to his office would have been what?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I understand what you've said about the cancer and I'm not going into that, but when you were going out with him to restaurants or when he would come to your office, right? Those were not sterile environments where they?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Oh, very sterile because it --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: A restaurant were a sterile environments?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: A lot of times we wouldn't eat there. We will pick up something and go in, but they were --

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I'm listening to you. You pick up and take it to where?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Maybe eat at our office, but it did not happen much. That's what I'm trying to explain to you in my office in 2020, nobody was coming in I was stir-crazy, so I would still go into my office. You remember when I started this, I said I am not even sure if we came to each other's offices, but I am trying to be over-cautious.So I think I can recall him at 750 a couple of times, I don't recall him as 750 once, but lets say twice. I have seen his office. I remember all the awards in the lobby, but I'm not sure in 2020 I went. I'm not even sure I went in 2020 at all. I just want to tell you. Yes, because I'm not sure, but I have -- I have a distinct recollection of him at 750. I actually don't have a distinct recollection of me. It is office in 2020, but maybe I went to his office in 2020. Maybe.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Did you have ongoing phone conversations during 2020 with Mr. Wade?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah. I talked to, yes, absolutely. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. No question about that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No question. I talked him on a phone in 2020.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I understood and this is -- maybe I was confused the Belize trip was for --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: His 50th birthday. SADOW

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: March, he turned 50, March 18th of 2023. If you look at the dates of the trip, and they're about six days. We stayed at two different locations.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And you paid for it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: One hundred percent. He said -- not only -- I mean, I paid for the hotel, I paid for the flights. I had a birthday luncheon for him. I paid for massages. I paid for everything.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And were those payments be reflected on your credit card?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I pay it with cash -- cab.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: You pay them with cash?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Cabs, cabs. I was telling him all the different things.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And I'm asking you whether or not those payments would be reflected on credit card bills of yours?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: There was about $500 that I think is reflected on a debit card. What my recollection is I took about four in cash with me.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Four hundred or 4,000?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Four thousands. But I remember I handed him 2,500 and then the rest was just the money we spent. I probably gave $300 or $400 to this guy who was a taxi driver. He would drive us every day around, the two or three days we went, took him to eat like it was my -- my trip money.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And you had to be clear to end this up. The four thousand that you've just told us --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: But I didn't give it all to him. Remember, I only gave the 2,500 to him.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: I didn't ask you that. I'm just going to ask you that 4,000 is part of your, my words, cash horde that you had collected over time?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Cash what?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: Horde, h-o-r-d-e.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I thought you said something different, sir?

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: No, I'm afraid I wouldn't say that any circumstances to you or in court.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: All right, back on track.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: To horde cash or debt.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I would not classify it in that way, but I have money at my house. Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: And the money -- when you had money at your house.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: When I'm speaking too loosely. I had money wherever I was stayed. So I was not referring to my house and 750, I'm saying I have money, wherever I was laying my head. Yes, sir. That was my fault that I wasn't clear.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: So when you were at what we've said, the Yeartie condom, during the time period we've always discussed. That's where you would keep your cash?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: When I stay there. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SADOW
utterances.sentences: That's all I have. Thank you

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: All right. I want to see if we can get through a few more defense counsel possible before breaking for today.Mr. Stockton?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Madam, this would turn out Mr. Allyn Stockton (ph), and I don't think we've had the pleasure of meeting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: It's a pleasure to meet you, sir.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Madam D.A., you described these various trips and Mr. Sadow asked you about going to Washington, did you and Mr. Wade go to New York?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You also said that he was a world traveler and been on many of the continents.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: He'd been to six.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Have you been on any of those continents with him? Besides this one?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Where's Belize? What continent is that? I'm not being funny. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let's say -- with the exemption --

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I've been to with Belize with him. I've been to the Bahamas with him. I've been to Aruba with him. Don't embarrass me. I'm not sure what continents those are on. Whatever continents those are, that's where I've been. I'm sure if I gave it some thought, I would tell you, but whatever continents those are that I've been to, those locations, sir.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: But not Australia or any other continents?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't even want to go to Australia. I do know he took a trip in December to Australia. I have no idea you know. I don't know anything about that trip.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: When Mr. Wade began working with your office?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He had two other gentlemen that worked in his firm with him. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Terrance Bradley worked for him and Chris Campbell were -- not for him. They work with each other.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did you understand what their partnership arrangement was?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did he ever make you aware of how fees were divided or anything?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Now, since you have been district attorney the two gentlemen that worked with Mr. Wade and his firm they also had contracts with your office, is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I probably had -- I don't --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: We already -- I don't know if we've covered this, Ms. Willis, but I still don't know what the relevance would be of her testifying to this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: But I've had about ten -- I'm sorry. Do you want me to answer this?

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Let's figure it out.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Judge, respectfully, I think based on Mr. Wade's testimony, he had an interest in those contracts.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Sure. And then -- but how's that been imputed to Ms. Willis?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I don't know if whether or not she knew she was giving him that benefit. That's what I was trying to explore.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Okay. Well, maybe we can start with that question and then if she doesn't know about it, then the ins and outs of all the contracts requires relevant.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Judge, to lay a foundation for that, though --

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Let's see where it takes us. Go ahead

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The two gentlemen that were in Mr. Wade's office, did they have what he thinks been referred to as a taint contract?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So let me be clear. Now, I may get the names wrong. When I first became D.A. is the office was not properly staffed and so I'm surprised any lawyer would take it, but I did a contract for $60 an hour to help us out with first appearance. That lasted a few months, okay?So I can't remember Bradley or Campbell had that. I'm sure we can have records and I can tell you which one, but I just can't remember now, I liked their experience. One had been -- Bradley had been a probation officer and a defense attorney. Campbell had been a police officer and defense attorney. There's a reason I'm telling you this. Then that contract, like I said, it didn't last long. It was just I was aggressively hiring, hiring, hiring, hiring. Soon as I got where I felt like I have first appearance, enough lawyers for that. I'll let them go. Then, we have what's called a filter contract, but it was not filter for this particular case. I do have a lawyer who does the filter for this election interference case. When were talking about filter the contract, they had that neither one of them has any longer. I now have another lawyer that does f for me. It was only for police brutality cases, is for what I call the -- so when I first got to be the D.A., I had -- the whole unit was called anticorruption. It dealt with both elections and police brutality cases. I actually took a trip to Houston and visited the district attorney in Houston. They divided their workup and I thought the way she was doing it was better than me. And so I made a civil rights unit. And so they did what we would classify as civil rights cases. Those are specifically the police brutality cases. When I first took over, I was told Paul had not filtered five cases. That was a joke. It ended up being the 101 cases. They weren't filtered, which is why I hired two of them. Eventually we got it down enough that it was one of them. And then now I still have one lawyer that does it. But now I've been able to cut those cases down to like 30.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Can you tell me the -- helped me understand what the purpose of the filter is?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So in the same private office, you had a filter contract, then you had somebody else having handling first appearances and so forth, and then you had a special prosecutor. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I' just not -- ultimately, the answer to your question is yes, but I'm not sure that they did it at the same time. The first appearance contract was either $60 or $90. I don't know really how I convinced them to be able to take that, but I think because it was such a short amount of time. And then I think I pay my filter lawyers which I still don't know how get away with, about 150 an hour.And I want you to understand, the AG pays special prosecutors $1,000 an hour. So I'm a tough negotiator. Paul was paying people up to 375 an hour. I won't pay anyone more than -- 250 is my max. I have a lot of lawyers that lot for what I have that work at 250 and I capped them every month. You can't go pass a certain amount of hours.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Would you agree that if Mr. Wade and the two other gentlemen that were in his firm were splitting fees in equal thirds, would you agree that he would benefit from the tank contract and also from the other first appearance contract?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I would agree he would make money, yeah. So to make money as a benefit.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Judge, it's all I got.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Durham, just with us on zoom?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No question.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Mr. MacDougald (ph).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I do have a couple, your honor, that's a little walker to come from back here.

utterances.speaker: JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Why don't you go ahead and make your way up?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Good afternoon, Ms. Willis. How are you doing?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I'm very well. How about you, Mr. McDougal? I think this is a first in-person meeting, correct?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Second.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Second, well, I apologize for my remembering you more clear.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: That's quite all right.I'm referring now to exhibit number 21.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Which was your financial disclosure form for 2022.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And it has a question which requires you to disclose any gifts or favors from a single prohibited source. In the aggregate amount of $100 or more. Do you see that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I don't, but I believe you --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It would be on page two in the middle, paragraph number three.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And what is your understanding of a prohibited source for purposes of this form?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: I believe there's some classification of somebody you like don't have a personal relationship with the gives you $100.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: If you let me under there, subparagraph 2, on that too, it defines it as someone that you know, or should know is seeking to do or is doing business with the county, correct?

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: Yes. But -- yes. Let me -- yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: That includes Mr. Wade as of the date you filled out this form, correct?
